channel.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
channel.description: Does anyone know how to upload a mixtape to YouTube without getting copyrighted? I have some of my stuff and some other peoples stuff. I tried uploading a mix once but it got blocked. If anyone knows it would be appreciated.

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
Soundcloud will only take down a mix at the request of a creator.

“It’s important to note takedowns are at the request of creators. While the agreements we have in place across the industry have greatly lessened the likelihood of takedowns, as a creator driven platform, we respect all creators, and therefore we respect the rights of all creators who request to have their content removed.”

FACT Magazine: Music News, New Music. – 12 Dec 16

SoundCloud DJ mixes no longer being taken down

DJ mixes posted on SoundCloud will no longer be taken down for copyright infringement, says SoundCloud founder Eric Wahlforss.

It’s also possible to upload a DJ mix (or remix) to Apple Music or Spotify through the Mixbank service provided by Dubset.

Read full topic

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: Norfleet
item.description:
HELIXX:

Don’t you have to pay for more minutes like SoundCloud

Mixcloud doesn’t have any upload limit. However, they have semi-strict licensing restrictions in the USA, so I’d look into that before uploading anything.

Read full topic
item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
El1011:

unless you have the explicit permission of the original artist/label, your remix is technically illegal (which is why it saying/believe remixes aren’t all copyrighted)

I’d assumed you were talking about official remixes.

Even so, even if it’s a ‘bootleg remix’ (unofficial, unsanctioned) then it’s still protected by copyright.
The elements from the original release will be copyrighted to the original artist/label/publisher* and the new production elements will be copyrighted to the remixer.

* and that’s a matter for the original copyright holder and the remixer to sort out

A remix would typically involve both copyright of the original recording (i.e. if using direct samples, acapellas, etc…) as well as publishing (e.g. if using the original melodies, etc…, but recreating them with new instruments/sounds).

 

unless you’re trying to make some $$ with it, not many people are gonna bother to get involved or sue u over it.

That’s kinda true. Your mix would still be a copyright infringement, regardless of whether it’s a ‘commercial release’ or not.
But as you say, it’s less likely that they’ll come after you. But, that’s down to the choices of the copyright holder, rather than the law.

It’s worth keeping in mind that even if you aren’t monetising it (e.g. not monetising the YT vid, or doing is as part of a free mixtape for self-promotion), it’s still a commercial promotion item, so still an attempt to generate commercial value. Just downstream.

If you’ve made money, and how much, mostly impacts on ‘damages’ — which is the additional money you can be sued for for ‘lost revenue’ as well as punitive amounts — if that’s the route the copyright holder chooses to take.

It’s also worth keeping in mind how easy it is for social platforms to identify infringing material because of smart algorithms. It’s likely that the DMCA claims are batch processed these days.

The fact that something’s still on YT doesn’t mean it hasn’t been hit with a DMCA. It could just mean that all the monetisation has been claimed by the copyright holders of the original material. Even if that’s only pennies, automation makes it easier to claim that too.

 

fair use

Nothing we’ve discussed so far would be covered by fair use.

Read full topic
item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
Well unless you have the explicit permission of the original artist/label, your remix is technically illegal (which is why it saying/believe remixes aren’t all copyrighted), however, unless you’re trying to make some $$ with it, not many people are gonna bother to get involved or sue u over it.

Who knows, I could be wrong, but from what I understand about how copyright/ fair use/ remixes/ bootlegs work, that’s what it seems

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
El1011:

i couldn’t find anything saying that remixes were copyrighted

What makes you think that remixes aren’t copyrighted?

(You probably couldn’t find anything specific because they’re not treated separately to any other original (artistic) creation.)

item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
“That doesn’t sound right, but i don’t know enough about spoiler copyright to dispute it”

nah, but 2 things:

  1. i couldn’t find anything saying that remixes were copyrighted
  2. it seems like most artist are fine with others using their remixes for stuff, which is why i think it would be better than to try and fight a label for their track. I’ve never seen anyone have a problem with someone else using their remix as much as i have seen for using the original pieces

item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
Well what tracks/labels are you pulling stuff from?
Some labels like Monstercat have a way u can use their stuff on their page. Others might just be copyright free, just add credit.

Also you could use a remix version or speed up/ slow down your mix a bit.

item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Of course, a lot of what’s being discussed here is really the monetisation.

If it’s simply about getting a mix up, and you’re not worried about getting revenue out of it, then generally speaking, you should be fine.

(Most music copyright holders in these situations prefer to let it stay up and just claim all or some of the revenue the video makes.)

Even if you’re not making money from that video, you can still start to build an audience. And that’s valuable in itself.

Read full topic

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: Norfleet
item.description:
El1011:

upposedly you can leave about 30-45 seconds of silence in the beginning and you should be fine.

That’s what I’ve heard and I’ve seen 1 track that was like that which seemed to work.

YouTube is always improving their system. A lot of times what you hear is outdated. A while back I uploaded a live mix and started recording about 10 minutes before the music started – it got, maybe, 15 claims. This was 6 months ago, so no doubt if it got claimed then, it’ll definitely get claimed now.

Read full topic
item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Even without/before any DMCA claims? Doesn’t sound right.

Not sure how much is getting taken down given that a quick and unscientific search for ‘mix’ on YT shows 250,000,000 matches - and mixes will often attract high views numbers, even on relatively small channels.

Of course, no idea how many of those have been hit with a DMCA claim, and either had their monetisation redirected to the copyright holder(s) or demonetised completely.

I’m not endorsing or recommending it, just pointing out that YT don’t seem overly bothered by their presence.

Read full topic
item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: El1011
item.description:
Supposedly you can leave about 30-45 seconds of silence in the beginning and you should be fine.

That’s what I’ve heard and I’ve seen 1 track that was like that which seemed to work.

(i should have noted that this was actually on SC, but someone else uploaded the remix to YT and seemed to have no problems with it so…)

Read full topic
item.source: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted

item.title: How do I upload a dj mix without getting copyrighted
item.dc:creator: Norfleet
item.description:
NickElle:

the mods take a lot of stuff down.

It’s true that YouTube does have a lot of moderators that can take videos down, but you’re thinking of the YouTube Content ID system, that fingerprints tracks and automatically detects them when you upload any video. It’s extremely unlikely that, say, Alan Walker’s manager found a DJ mix with 5 views and flagged the video.

On that note… the fingerprinting system doesn’t always block your mixes. It can also just monetize them, and receive a portion of the ad revenue depending on how many claims you’ve received on that video.

Read full topic
